A solar eclipse would require the sun and the moon to travel at different speeds in the sky. Currently they travel at exactly the same speed and are exactly opposite in the sky, so a solar eclipse is impossible.

That said, it would be cool to have the sun and the moon travel at different speeds (very slight) and that on rare occasions the moon actually moves in front of the sun causing a solar eclipse. Special mobs could appear on these days, or special magical effects happen.

As much as I would love to see an eclipse in minecraft, it's simply not practical for the current game. The cycle of the sun and moon helps players track the time during day/night. It's a constant cycle that's a core part of the game. Having eclipses would require differentiating speeds of the sun and moon, and would completely remove the ability to track day and night (particularly night). Having a more unrealistic version of an eclipse, like a small random chance that the sun happens to be eclipsed when it rises would be more fitting. This would be the only way I would see it realistically possible without changing core elements of the game.

That's a great idea! I reckon the whole organisation of the world should be changed to get eclipses in Minecraft. I think when you first use a brewing stand you should have one available recipe: awkward potion. Once you have made that one, you either gain one recipe chosen at random, or the recipe for a basic potion of swiftness. (or maybe none! just guess!)

Loot chests can contain knowledge books for new recipes, eg:

-Underwater chests can contain water breathing or turtle master recipes

-Nether chests (fortress or bastion) can contain fire resistance, strength, or regeneration recipes, or knowledge of potent potions (as these are the ingredients you can find in the nether)

-Igloos with a basement can contain the recipe for weakness, because that is where you can learn about curing zombie villagers

-Strongholds can contain knowledge of how to make a lingering potion (preparing you to collect dragons breath before killing the dragon)

-End cities can contain the recipe for potion of slow falling

-Cleric villagers can sell at master level a recipe for a random potion

-And any other loot chest could have a chance to contain any other potion recipe, others being swiftness, slowness, leaping, healing, harming, poison, night vision, invisibility, splash potions, extended potions. (I couldn't think of appropriate places for these recipes)

I don't think this should be added.

What I don't think many people are realising about this is the greater disadvantage it would put mobile and console players in. Imagine a Skywars game; a player on PC would be able to loot chests and organise their inventory so much faster than a console player. Currently mobile players can organise the fastest because they can just select the item they want to move and just tap the slot where they want it to go. However, this isn't unbalanced as mobile players are already at a significant disadvantage just by being on mobile. PC players already have the advantage over console players just by being able to hotkey.

 

I used to think it should be added because yes, it would be nice. Then I thought a little bit and realised that it would just make PvP more imbalanced. Maybe when more servers have input based matchmaking it would make more sense but currently, I am fully against it.

I’ve spent around 8-16 hours on two separate hardcore runs in the nether (starting with no supplies). I was able to reach a point when I could reasonably survive long-term, though the main issue with the nether right now is that a Nomadic Live-style is the only way to progress.

Theres no cobblestone or leather, so you’ll be stuck with wood tools & no armor for most of the time. No furnaces so no way to cook hoglin food (when it comes). The only source of iron and diamonds is in fortress chests, which is a lot of rng.

The main thing that makes the nomadic life-style unappealing (aside from no base), is the fact that the nether is hard to transverse. With no access to potion materials (bottles, water) means no fire resistance potions. Carefully scaling up and down the terrain is tedious, which is only made worse by the fact that most of the terrain lacks any sort of useful resources (only wood & mushrooms).

Maybe soul sand valleys could have a sort of “silver oak” tree, with stone leaves and logs that drop iron nuggets when stripped.

I support the idea of adding this feature as a default, especially for those who prefer a more laid-back experience. My friends and I often switch to Peaceful or Easy modes while building, and we always get a kick out of one of us managing to die on an easier difficulty and have dubbed the trek to our stuff "The Walk of Shame." That said, I’d love to see a toggle for "Keep Inventory" and "Keep Experience" that would automatically enable on Peaceful or Easy, but also give players the option to disable it for those who want to maintain the traditional benefits of lower difficulties. Minecraft is all about customization, so more options to adjust gameplay would be ideal. A toggle system would allow players to enjoy "Keep Inventory" on higher difficulties like Normal and Hard, offering flexibility for those who want to focus more on creative exploration without the penalty of losing items. Anyway that's been my Ted Talk, thanks for reading my novel!

I think Keep Inventory should scale depending on the difficulty. For instance, there's Keep Inventory on Peaceful, but it's slightly different on Easy. For easy, all items drop, but XP decreases to three levels, rather than all of them as it is in the game right now. In addition, the items and XP despawn after 30 minutes, instead of five minutes by default. On Normal, it's also a little bit different. All the items drop, XP decreases to five levels, and everything despawns after 15 minutes. On Hard (and hardcore), all items drop, XP decreases to ten levels, and despawning happens after five minutes. This level of scaling would be better depending on which difficulty people choose. Incorporating this premise into the game would be good for Bedrock and Java.

"Why not do it like this:

In 'Easy' mode, you keep everything in your hotbar but lose everything else. Some achievements, like 'Kill X monsters,' are disabled. In 'Peaceful' mode, all achievements are disabled, and you keep your entire inventory.

Alternatively, a popup could appear when starting a new map in 'Easy' or 'Peaceful' mode, informing the player that achievements will be disabled if they choose to enable 'Keep Inventory.'

For players who already have a world in 'Easy' or 'Peaceful' mode, they can select the 'Keep Inventory' option in the world editing screen. A popup will notify them: 'If you enable this feature, you will no longer be able to earn achievements.' This setting cannot be changed within the world and must be adjusted in the world editing screen.

Players who already have an 'Easy' or 'Peaceful' world before this update would still follow the old rules until they make the changes as described."

I think a key part in the discourse of KeepInventory is that there lacks a way to distinguish the difference between a person who plays in one playstyle or the other. And so, having it be accessible to all can feel like it diminishes the efforts of those who play without that safety net. But that’s what everyone understands about this.

While it might be more work, I believe the best way of handling this is to have an icon in the inventory that indicates keepinventory is active, similar to how hearts are labeled differently for hardcore. This ends up legitimizing both ways of playing.

Then, the toggle could be moved out of the ‘Cheats’ section, as the icon appearing in the inventory would handle much of the tension around the topic.

Could people still switch it on and off when it suits them after the world has been generated? That would have to be a design decision on Mojang’s end. But as long as this is properly handled, having the different difficulties have different base gamerules wouldn’t be too troublesome to manage after that.

As someone who has a survival server where the players vary wildly in age, this is a good change.  Younger and less experienced players have a lot of trouble with losing their items, and older or more experienced players mostly find regaining their items to be annoying. Turning on Keep Inventory resulted in younger players having a much better time, and older players liked not having to worry about grinding for rare gear (such as the mace) again if something happened to them.

However, we have noticed that players sometimes use it as a free teleport home button - which is probably not in line with how you want players to interact with death. Having some consequence like losing your XP would solve this to a certain extent. We tried implementing this with command blocks but it was rather buggy so we stopped, but when it worked it was a good compromise.

On the whole, I would like to see significantly more options around player death be surfaced by player / server settings. More granular settings for player death would be useful for getting community feedback as well.

I think a middle ground would make the most sense. The easiest way would be a death chest (it would function slightly differently to a normal chest) or gravestone, you still lose your items but there's no chance of them de-spawning.

Firstly, regarding the KeepInventory change, I think it should go like this;

  • Upon dying in Peaceful mode you should keep 2/3 of your inventory *2/3 of your XP you keep*
  • Upon dying in Easy mode you should keep 1/3 of your inventory *1/3 of your XP you keep*

This way it isn't you lose everything, but you lose mostly everything, allowing to feel less frustrating, but also not just extremely easy, and death having no penalty. And yes, you can always go back and pick-up your items you lost.

In-terms of the main difficulty, changes should be made, and maybe not all just for making it harder.

  • Peaceful: 2/3 of your inventory you keep upon death, 0.0x mob spawn multiplier, 0.5x hostile mob damage multiplier 0.5x hostile mob health, 1.5x ores, 0.75x XP multiplier.
  • Easy: 1/3 of your inventory you keep upon death, 0.5x mob spawn multiplier, 0.75x hostile mob damage multiplier 0.75x hostile mob health, 1.25x ores, 0.75x XP multiplier.
  • Normal: None of your inventory you keep upon death, 1.0x mob spawn multiplier, 1.0x hostile mob damage multiplier 1.0x hostile mob health, 1.0x ores 1.0x XP multiplier.
  • Hard: None of your inventory you keep upon death, 1.5x mob spawn multiplier, 1.5x hostile mob damage multiplier 1.5x hostile mob health, 0.75x ores 1.25x XP multiplier.

This is a much more balanced version of difficulties, and probably will separate every one. *There will still be hidden changes as well!*

The three main dangers of losing items on death are as follows:

  • The player does not have the items anymore (obviously!)
  • The items will despawn if the player is too slow in getting back to them (assuming they're in a loaded chunk)
  • The player may not remember where they died

I have seen a proposal in these comments to allow players to keep only the items in their hotbar, and I believe this is an idea worth exploring. I would also increase the despawn time on items that were dropped on death so as to give players a bit more time to plan out a recovery expedition and figure out where they died.

If you die in Peaceful, you keep all of your items and xp. Die in Easy, and you lose half your xp, but still keep all your items. Dying in Normal could cost you all of your xp and make you drop only a few random items from your inventory, or maybe everything in your hotbar. Adding in my two cents - I'm generally in agreement that making Keep Inventory more accessible is a good thing, but that letting a player keep their full inventory by just changing the difficulty is the wrong way to go about it. Death, as a mechanic, is meant to be a punishment for poor gameplay. Without the threat of losing your inventory, it becomes at best a very minor nuisance (I wasn't done exploring that cave but whatever) and at worst an active benefit (I'll just jump off this cliff and get a free ticket to spawn).

There are two options that make sense to me within Minecraft's framework:
1) Terraria-style difficulty. Keep peaceful, easy, medium, and hard as-is, and have a secondary difficulty option for Keep Inventory, no Keep Inventory, and Hardcore (permadeath). This allows players to easily choose their preferred mix of difficulty settings without having to dig through menus to find the right options. This also makes server management easier, as the choice of inventory management is explicit rather than implicit.
2) Keep Inventory "lite." If we insist on tying Keep Inventory to world difficulty, it may be better to introduce an in-between "mode" that reduces the punishment of dying but allows it to remain an undesirable outcome. An example (though by no means the best) would be for the player to lose some portion of their ores or mob drops on death. This allows them to still make net progress while incentivizing them to avoid death as much as possible.

There are major problems with having keep inv on by default and not explicitly giving them a way to disable that feature. Not to mention the impact this change will have on the speed running community which utilizes the differences between normal and easy to speed run the game. I could dive deep into the problems but I believe everyone else on this forum will have already done so.

Solutions:
Solution 1: (least effort) make it so easy mode keep inv is off and peaceful mode keep inv is on. This wont affect the SR community at all as a run is invalid if swapped to peaceful. It will still make easy more challenging for players. And it makes a lot of sense that peaceful mode the mode with 0 hostile mobs also has 0 consequences if a player dies.
Solution 2: Add an in-between for easy and normal where easy would still be keep inv but the in-between would have the current "easy mode" rules. Doing this would also open avenues for an Ultra hard mode or an in-between for Normal and Hard mode which could be exciting and add new extreme challenges to the game without moding (similar to terraria's for the worthy, ect.)
Solution 3: On easy instead of it being a fully fledged keep inv, instead replace that with a keep hotbar or keep XP. Something less powerful than literally 0 loss. I personally still don't love this solution but I could see how the community more broadly would still entertain this idea. The MCSR scene would definitely undergo some decent changes but nothing it can't handle.

It is a great concept and would be fun to have as an ability to toggle if you are considering keep inventory less as a "Cheat" and more as a feature to help new players in playing Minecraft, though, it may change the way we perceive the "Authentic Survival Experience." Firstly, a conflict that may occur later on if you end up implementing it "as is" or similar to how it is in the previews right now would be further increasing the difficulty spike from Peaceful or Easy to Normal and eventually Hard and Hardcore. While the proposed update to "Keep Inventory" aims to ease gameplay in Easy and Peaceful modes, retaining the current system is crucial for several reasons.

1. Preserving Challenge and Gameplay Integrity: Minecraft has always balanced challenge and reward. Losing items upon death adds tension and strategy, fostering a sense of accomplishment. If players retain inventory, it diminishes this feeling, making the game less engaging and trivializing risk.

2. Impact on Game Dynamics: Allowing players to keep items alters multiplayer experiences. In cooperative play, retaining inventory can lead to reckless behavior, undermining teamwork and respect for environmental challenges. This change could diminish the collaborative spirit that makes multiplayer enjoyable.

3. De-emphasizing Skill Development: Minecraft encourages skill growth through exploration and resource management. Retaining items reduces the incentive to improve. The current system motivates players to navigate danger thoughtfully, while less challenge may lead to stagnation in player development.

4. Nature of Survival Modes: As a survival game, Minecraft inherently involves risks and consequences. Altering rules in Easy and Peaceful modes undermines survival gameplay, which is about managing risks. Keeping the current system preserves the core mechanics that define the game.

5. Preserving Achievement Integrity: While not considering "Keep Inventory" a cheat may seem beneficial, it risks ruining the value of achievements.

I'm a purist and I somewhat disagree with this change. On peaceful difficulty, I could see arguments supporting implementing this change, as many beginner players already know that peaceful is the easiest and safest way to play the game, so I believe this adds another element of convenience and improves quality of life. However, I do not feel the same way about the implementation in easy mode. Once hostile mobs are introduced, I believe that players should become familiar with the risks associated with encountering hostile mobs throughout the world. This change highlights Mojang's interest in catering towards every play style, but as it stands, currently exposes itself as solely catering towards beginner players. If the keep inventory option was moved to a more prominent page that a beginner is more likely to see, or another element/greater difficulty was introduced for the harder difficulties to balance out this change, an update to the difficulty system in Minecraft could successfully cater to all play styles without compromising one of the game's most integral components.

Achievements, in my mind, are awards for completing tasks while surviving. Removing the motivation or need to survive would remove some merit or sense of accomplishment from earning achievements. However, I do think that an easier mode for new players is a good idea. I think that there should be a separate tutorial mode that is in every way the same but allows for keep inventory and other modifications to make the game easier. This mode could also have a progression chart that is world specific that would provide new players a sense of accomplishment. This mode would allow new players to experience a less punishing survival Minecraft experience without changing the core of the game that some players have been enjoying for 12 years.

I think that the best way to handle this is to make it so that it ONLY applies to the Peaceful difficulty. My reasoning is that those who play on this difficulty are likely either newer or want a much smaller challenge. Giving them Keep Inventory would not change much in this sense.

Meanwhile, on Easy mode, you still want a challenge, you just may not be ready for something like Normal mode yet. In this case, Keep Inventory should be turned off. This way, newer players can start to understand what it would mean to play on higher difficulties while still not being bombarded by damage, and otherwise players who may be looking for a more casual experience can still play the game they know and love as they remember it.

The next problem is achievements, and I think the best way to solve that in this case is to remove the ability to get achievements while on peaceful mode.

These are decent changes, but you should also at least notify the player that keep inventory will be on in some way, or do something like move or add the keep inventory button to the difficulty buttons so you can freely enable and disable it.

PLEASE do not add this feature, easy mode shouldn't mean the game literally wipes your butt for you. keep inventory entirely removes any semblance of risk minecraft has. whats the point in not running around an ancient city if you can just set your spawn with a bed in the city and have literally no downside to dying? whats the point of being careful in the end while getting elytra if falling in the void doesnt do anything other than effectively teleport you back to your spawnpoint? keep inventory should stay in the game, but it should be considered a cheat, as that is what it is.

I think that this would be a great idea if applied to other armor sets, too! If we wind up getting any more armor tiers in the future, we're not going to be able to have a linear progression system anymore, because it will simply be too long, and in my opinion, this is not sustainable.

In a small armor tree, like in pre-1.16, each tier of equipment was meaningful because it represented a significant step forward in the game. But, for instance, if intermediate armor sets like Copper were inserted into the tree, it would turn into something like Final Fantasy: You buy a bunch of equipment for your party, only to sell it all 15 minutes later when you get to the next town and buy the next best thing. That would only incentivize players to skip entire tiers of equipment to avoid the hassle. I would be frustrated if I was suddenly forced to mine Copper before I was able to get Iron equipment, or make steel before I could mine diamonds. But if those equipment sets gave me an advantage that Iron or Diamond couldn't, I might pursue them despite their lower stats.

If the game shifted to allowing side-grades of armor, with different pros and cons coming with each, it might make the player's choice of equipment in a vast sea of options more meaningful.

I definitely like the idea of being able to repurpose the towers.

That said, it really isn't a "bit of a task." I have twice now started a game in view of a tower, and both times I stormed it without doing anything at all beyond picking up a block of dirt. I ran for the tower and ran inside... the first time having no idea what to expect, but figuring it was a fun way to start. I found the door easily and took one hit on the run to get there. I ran up the stairs and no one was inside the tower waiting. Those giving chase were not close enough behind to get a shot off as I wound up the stairs. At the top, I turned and used the dirt to block the stairs. I then had all the time in the world to loot the chest as they grunted beneath me. I turned to go and had to drop from the tower, but probably should have just run through them.

The second time was even easier. I cased the place from a distance (they patrol and will attack if you are too close) and found the entrance in advance. I got a good line on the door and ran for it. No damage. Same deal, got the loot, and this time there's a pond beneath me, so I just run off the top of the tower. No damage at the bottom. One of them gave chase for a long time and got two hits, but I emerged unscathed and healed with the food I just stole from the tower chest along with the rest of the loot that included a crossbow and some other good starter stuff.

In other words... yes, I like your idea. No, I don't think it's much of a task to get the top of the tower if it can be done at the very beginning of a game.

I would like to add my support for this suggestion, with some further comments and tweaks. I think that instead of pillagers randomly spawning around the terrain of the outpost, there should be a finite count of them associated with it. Perhaps 50 would be a good number? After they are defeated, the outpost is yours, to destroy or repurpose.

Pillager outposts add something fun and challenging to the game. But I don't think the pillagers themselves should be randomly blinking on and off like the ghoulish nighttime mobs of skeletons and zombies. Somehow that feels wrong. It makes them seem less like human entities and more like, well, just random generated mobs. With a finite count of pillagers in the forts, we have a pathway to victory and closure.

As fun as the pillagers are, it's actually pointless to engage with them. We need a reason to interact with pillager outposts. There needs to be a way to conquer them, even if it's really hard to do so. That would encourage the player to strategize the best way to topple the towers and even repurpose them, if desired. As it stands now, I just ignore the outposts, having learned what I did about them. After all, what's the point?

I have tried everything. I destroyed their home. I burned the grass, put some wood over it and they keep on spawning. I am playing in survival hardcore mode. But the fact that they keep spawning no matter what on the same location is truly annoying. Is there any way to stop that?

If you're willing, you can place a repeating command block with the following command in the center of the top floor of the tower:

tp @e[type=pillager] ~ -100 ~

This will keep the entity count low as opposed to killing the pillagers with a command and having their loot drop all over the place. You may want to turn off command block output as every time it sends one into the void it will tell you in the chat.

I have my command block set up to be redstone dependent. I put the command block in the center of the floor, a quartz block with a switch attached covering it, and a redstone lamp on top that indicates if the command block is receiving redstone power. Lamp on = no pillagers. Lamp off = normal amount of pillagers.

It is a decent temporary fix to something that will hopefully be updated later on. Plus it makes for a great challenge between players to see who can light the lamp first.

Here's my general thoughts:

1. Have a special banner or block in the center of the top story of the tower. When a player claims it, pillagers stop spawning. The pillagers prevously spawned do not despawn. This would make it so that a player still has to fight to take the outpost, not just be fast and grab the banner.

That requires being able to conquer the outposts- and for the pillagers to be able to take it back. I believe I have figured out a way to solve this issue (I too think that skins would be great to show off):

Have two toggle options:

  • Show/Hide personal armor
  • Show/Hide other player's armor

I have an alternative pitch on how to implement. Instead of something as tacky and obvious as a boss battle, instead go back to the legend’s roots. Add extremely rare small structures that can generate (Random 1x2 mines with torches, connected to nothing, small sand towers nearish to the coasts, etc.) Something that can spawn, but not so often that you maybe even see one every game. Have a chance for a non-legible name tag to momentarily spawn in an open space at least 20 blocks away from the player, and only momentarily. I was going to suggest this myself, I figured it must have been suggested before but it's not on the "previously considered" list so I had a few ideas for it.

One would be an item system that makes use of the enchantment table, albeit a bit differently. For example, a wand that can be charged using XP in order to cast offensive spells, or perhaps a single-use piece of paper similar to the spell scrolls from ES. Or maybe papers/other items, trinkets etc. could be used for utility spells.

The other idea was a magic system entirely different from but somewhat similar to the enchanting table, being able to "learn" a spell for a limited number of casts. Either way I would expect offensive spellcasting to be a limited-use thing reliant on exp.

I hadn't thought of it but I really like the idea of using some form of ritual as suggested earlier. For example, creating some sort of sigil on the ground and burning(?) it or something in order to charge a wand/staff or regain casting ability, etc. Maybe in addition to using exp at a table of sorts?

Edit: Another idea, if implemented, maybe the damage or usefulness of spells could be inversely proportional to the quality of armor equipped? Just a thought.

I’ve been wanting a magic update for so long too. We know evokers can use spells like summoning vexs and the crocodile snap type things. We also know players can tap into the power of potions and enchanting. Souls are also used in Minecraft dungeons as magical energy. Imagine what sort of stories players could create if these mechanics were expanded on in the base game. Survival builders could make so many different designs for building around different systems.
What if lapis combine with soul sand and perhaps the potion ingredient could create throw able projectiles. Not necessarily potion effects, but what if soul sand + plus lapis + a fire charge or blaze powder gave you a flaming projectile the player can actually throw. Maybe a splash potion of healing plus some other ingredient could make a throw able instant health projectile with a farther throwing range.
I know some of these ideas may sound a little bit modded, but as long as it sticks with in the one action/one block at a time model, I don’t think it could be too busted or difficult for other players to follow what you’re doing.
Maybe there could also be more mobs with different magic resistances or sensitivities like we do now with witches and the undead.
